justification: “Decision-making under risk was assessed with the ‘hot’ version of the Columbia Card Task (Figner et al., 2009).”
“We assessed working memory with the WAIS-IV digit span task (backwards and sequencing scores) (Wechsler, 2008).”
Participants’ “social and role functioning in the past month [were measured] with the Global Functioning Scales Social and Role Scale,” which contains a separate Social subscale.
The same sentence notes that role functioning was obtained with the Global Functioning Scales, whose Role subscale targets role performance in work, school, or homemaking.

“Symptoms in the SSD group [were measured] with the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS)… Sum scores were calculated on five dimensions – positive, negative, disorganized, excited, and depressed.”
The PANSS five-factor scoring includes a distinct Negative symptom dimension, derived from the same scale mentioned above.
The article states that PANSS scores were broken down so that “disorganized” symptoms could be analyzed as one of the five dimensions.
PANSS dimensional scores also included an “excited” factor, as referenced in the sentence describing the five-factor model.
The same passage lists “depressed” as one of the PANSS dimensions, indicating that depressive symptom severity was obtained from this instrument.
